results.title: Fire down below
results.creator_credit: Mike Weatherley and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
David Bellamy celebrates Christmas in Australia. Instead of holly a banksia decorates his Christmas pudding, and, as the brandy burns, the plant provides clues to the secrets of survival of the Australian flora against the frequent fires which seek to destroy it. Narrated by David Bellamy.

results.title: Fire chief
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: First released in 1941, this film features the best from the second decade of the “Donald Duck” cartoons. This short is filled with one clever gag after another as Donald has a go at being fire chief.

results.title: Fire awareness
results.brief_description: Discusses the nature of fire awareness and looks at the nature of fire, the causes of fire, the behaviour of fire and fire safety management. Also looks at fire prevention, protection and supression. Technical advice for the video was supplied by the Metropolitan Fire Brigade, and Fire Prevention Department, Melbourne. A manual complements the video and is issued as a separate loan item.

results.title: Fire's the enemy
results.brief_description: Shows recent developments in civil defence training: the latest fire-fighting equipment; emergencies a community may have to cope with during a serious outbreak and how the individual as well as the community may deal with an actual attack. Training of new recruits is also described.

results.title: Fire's on - Lapstone tunnel by Arthur Streeton, 1891
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton, Art Gallery of New South Wales and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Australian eye I”.
The death of a workman during blasting of the railway tunnel at Lapstone in the NSW Blue Mountains in 1891 was Arthur Streeton’s inspiration for this painting. Streeton’s vivid description of the accident in a letter to his artist friend Tom Roberts is included in the commentary. Written by David Muir and edited by Ian Walker.
results.title_for_label: Fire’s on - Lapstone tunnel by Arthur Streeton, 1891
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Muir, Malcolm Otton, Art Gallery of New South Wales and Film Australia

results.title: Fire
results.brief_description: This film shows the bushfires which wiped out the town of Dwellingup and Nangabrook in Western Australia in January 1961. From the first outbreaks through the five day bushfire raging through jarrah forest, pasture and townships. The volunteer firefighters in action, attempts to plough or burn firebreaks, the trail of damage left behind, the relief work, rebuilding and new growth after the fire.

results.title: Fire
results.brief_description: Animated impressionistic film portraying an idyllic forest alive with plants and animals that suddenly grows quiet as ominous clouds of black smoke roll over the landscape, and fire consumes everything in its path.

results.title: Finger painting
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the activities of children creating patterns in paint working with the hands, fingers and thumbs. Quotes a recipe for making special finger paint; shows the use of special paper; demonstrates actual teaches for applying colour. This film is designed to leave the imagination free.
